title: Profit breakdown puts dent in Flight Centre
text:
More detailed guidance was to be issued at the company’s annual general meeting in November.

The forecast was released as Flight Centre presented at a conference for stockbrokers Morgans, which was not open to the public.

Morgans analysts had recently warned that Flight Centre’s profit forecast for the year, likely to be given at the company’s AGM, “could be weaker than the market expects”.

Other analysts had been divided on the outlook for the company too, with some questioning any turnaround in Australia.

Flight Centre chief executive Graham Turner said in the announcement that results would be “heavily weighted” towards the second half. Stabilisation in the business was expected during the second quarter after a “challenging” first quarter, he said.

While the amount of travel transactions flowing through Flight Centre were increasing in Australia, he reaffirmed that the company had “not yet seen any tangible benefits flowing from recent interest rate cuts and tax refunds”.

Any benefits were more likely to be seen later in [this financial year], “assuming consumer confidence improved ahead of the year’s peak booking periods for longer haul holidays”, he said.

Advertisement

Flight Centre confirmed that the UK collapse of travel outfit Thomas Cook had had minimal impact on the company.

Mr Turner at the conference highlighted that online leisure sales were increasing rapidly in Australia. One example was its flightcentre.com.au site notching 65 per cent growth in the first quarter in terms of total transactions, which includes money Flight Centre passes on to other companies such as airlines.

“This growth is predominantly coming from domestic travellers who are new to the Flight Centre brand, rather than from existing customers who are moving between sales channels, pointing to increased market share over the period,” Mr Turner said.

Flight Centre recorded underlying 12-month profits of $343 million last year.
description: Travel outfit warns that the good times in early 2019 are unlikely to be repeated in first-half earnings.
